intro: Gilia aggregata subvar. helleri, commonly known as Heller's gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, clustered pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has hairy, branched stems. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a waxy coating to reduce water loss. The flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
